entry.title: Sigma.js
entry.content: I'm looking forward to playing with this to generate all kinds of directed graphs for visualizations, even if I just use it to make fancy wallpapers for my tablet or something. Can't think of an immediate use for this but I'll keep it in the back of my mind.

entry.title: Chromecast now open to developers with the Google Cast SDK
entry.content: This is pretty cool. My roommate has a TV that accepts casts from certain applications such as YouTube and we've had some fun with playing with the JavaScript SDK to push random videos to the TV at any time. I might have Rick Rolled him in the middle of watching TV before...

entry.title: Dev Ops cheatsheet
entry.content: This is a handy reference for some interesting devops-y tips and tricks. The page says Ruby, but most of the things listed are general practice and not specifically Ruby.

entry.title: CoffeeScript 1.7 released
entry.content: New version of CoffeeScript is released today. Pretty cool enhancements but none I'm super excited about it, though. The new operators are pretty cool, however. I haven't been using Coffee lately as much as I used to, even sometimes electing to use JS when I could have used Coffee. Not sure why that is.

entry.title: Internet Explorer (8) Array.sort Unreliable
entry.content: Fought this dumb bug at work today. In sorting functions given to Array.prototype.sort() in JavaScript, if you reassign argument variables' values in the function, IE8 may completely break on you, sometimes resulting in one or both of your comparison values becoming undefined randomly. Though it makes no sense JavaScript-wise, to fix this bug, you have to declare your own, separate variables for your values.

entry.title: Coding in color
entry.content: This is a cool idea. I've never actually thought about syntax highlighting, but now that I do, it does seem kind of not terribly helpful. I definitely notice it if it's not there, but I'm not sure I could tell you the specific color of a piece of code (variable declarations are blue, etc.). It's entirely subconscious.

entry.title: A Nerd in a Cave
entry.content: Way too much honesty here. The Zone we creative types work in is such a fickle thing, leading to irrational responses to anything that threatens it while we're in it. A nice write-up for friends and significant-others of creative types, explaining why if you interrupt The Zone and we're mean to you, we're sorry, but it's no one's fault.

entry.title: Trello boards made to load 87% faster
entry.content: A really nice write-up about how to tackle common front-end application performance bottlenecks. I've employed a few of these tricks myself in the past to achieve better performance in slower browsers (I'm looking at you, IE).

entry.title: EasyStar.js
entry.content: This is a really cool pathfinding library using the A* Search Algorithm. It's designed for adding to your games and other JavaScript apps where pathfinding plays a role. Check out their website for a snazzy demonstration of the library guiding a group of soldiers across a randomly generated terrain.

entry.title: Who Owns?
entry.content: Nice article here by Zach Holman discussing insecurity around public expression on the web.

entry.title: Symbolset icons
entry.content: This is a really nice collection of icons for purchase. Might have to keep my eye on these for future use.

entry.title: 4K is for programmers
entry.content: Interesting read about using a low-price 4K television as a computer display for development. I'm not sure how I feel about using this high of resolution as a computer display, though. It's entirely too many pixels for me, I feel like.
